definitions.definition: useful, easy or quick to do; not causing problems
definitions.sensetop: convenient for somebody/somethingit is convenient to do somethingit is convenient for somebody to do somethingconvenient to do

examples.text: Fruit is a convenient source of vitamins and energy.
A bicycle is often more convenient than a car in towns.
I can't see him now—it isn't convenient.
I'll call back at a more convenient time.
For now, the most **convenient way** to access the internet remains the smartphone.
He used his wife's birthday as a convenient excuse for not going to the meeting.
He said meeting in Adelaide would be convenient for him as well.
When would be convenient for a visit?
It is very convenient to pay by credit card.
examples.contextForm: it is convenient to do something

examples.text: It's much more convenient for me to drive there.
examples.contextForm: it is convenient for somebody to do something

examples.text: You'll find these meals quick and convenient to prepare.
We arranged a mutually convenient time to meet.
Would this be convenient for you?
He used his wife's birthday as a convenient excuse for not going to the meeting.
Holding the debate at that time was not politically convenient.
I can't see them now. It's not convenient.
Wait for a convenient moment to talk to her.
We'll arrange a mutually convenient meeting place.

definitions.definition: near to a particular place; easy to get to

examples.text: The office is just five minutes from the station, so it's very convenient.
The house is very convenient for several schools.
The house is quite convenient for the shops.
The hotel is convenient to downtown.

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘befitting, becoming, suitable’): from Latin convenient- ‘assembling, agreeing, fitting’, from the verb convenire ‘assemble, agree, fit’, from con- ‘together’ + venire ‘come’.
